segments.text: I have a 15-second delay.

Once you then talk about these kinds of guidelines, management, in effect, mariculture, aquaculture, pollution control, work with the oceans, climate and climatology, then when you're looking at proposals or these sorts of things that you try to direct research into,

In our program now, what we do is describe the area, the general programmatic area that we're interested in, and then discuss with the scientific community what kinds of research ought to be done, and essentially respond to the community as they consider these regions
or these areas and decide from a scientific point of view what they think ought to be done.
And what happens is that we finally get a strong enough signal that a particular limited part of a program area should be tackled.
Some of the scientists who are going to lead it stand up and say, look, it's time that we started working on this question.
And then what we go through is a series of steps.

If the area is not well enough known, and in most cases it's not, then we sponsor a workshop in which all the experts in that particular area of research gather and discuss the status of knowledge and what are the gaps in the status of knowledge, and do a tentative design on a research project to fill in some of those gaps.

either at that meeting or shortly thereafter, either by osmosis or by election or by some process, a handful of leaders will take the leadership and say, OK, we're going to organize a research program.
And now we insist that they make this known to the community by putting an ad in Science or someplace saying, we're going to prepare a proposal along these lines of the National Science Foundation.
Anyone who has interest and good ideas on how this
Problems should be tackled.
Send us a letter and give us your thoughts.
If it fits, we'll incorporate it into the task.
And if it doesn't, we'll say so.
And if you don't like our answers, go see the foundation and tell them that we're giving you a bad time.
Good shape.
Now, a couple of questions now very quickly on you concerning personal comments, which you may choose to ignore, by the way.

For example, given the way that the problems you see facing this country, let's say that in terms of nuclear energy, with energy being overlapping problems, what's your attitude towards developing nuclear energy and nuclear waste?
Do you feel it should be stopped?
Should it be continued?
Do you feel as if the oceans can serve as sort of a waste deposit?
That's strange.
If you had asked me that two months ago, I would have said,
No problem.
Don't worry about it.
But unfortunately, between then and now, I read this rather excellent book on We Almost Lost Detroit is the title of it.
And it concerns some accidents that we've already had using fast breeder reactors and water-cooled reactors.
And my opinion was that we had
self-quenching cooling fluids for use in these reactors.
And it was impossible for them to get out of hand, because if the neutron flux got too high, why, the material would just become opaque to neutron flux, and it would shut down.
But apparently, this stuff, the fusion, the uranium and the thorium don't behave like they should.
And I guess they develop hotspots within the core.
And once the hot spot develops, it can do some damage to the cooling system, to the flow of it.
And then it ceases to be cooled correctly, and that hot spot continues to get hotter.
And so now I'm convinced that probably, unless we can deal effectively with that, and I don't think we can, that we probably shouldn't be using fission as a major source of heat.
a power in the future, and it's too bad because it's so attractive otherwise.
I think they can deal effectively with the waste.
That's not my concern.
My concern is that they are going to have some bad accidents and that those accidents are going to do a lot of harm to a lot of people.
So I'm not sure it's worth the gamble.
Are you optimistic about the ocean as a producer of food, as an oceanographer?
Oh, I think so.
I think my view is that now we're about the same point that the country was in 1860 when we were hunting buffalo.
If we had continued to improve our ability to hunt buffalo, they would have disappeared even faster.
Instead, we learn how to farm and to husband cows and to actually feed them and collect them together, essentially the farming effort that's going on.
And I think once we stop worrying about improving our ability to catch fish, start worrying more about how to farm the seeds, that the seeds can really, you know, they can, I think the potential for,
supplying proteins is certainly not unlimited, but it certainly goes orders of magnitude over above what we're talking about now in the sustained yield of the oceans in the natural conditions.
Third comment, then, on these fields you've defined as pressing fields, I suppose.
How successful will we be in mining the ocean, producing finite resources from the ocean, at a cost
which is within some kind of a bottom line in terms of cost.
Well, I'm certainly not an expert, but I was exposed to a rather thorough briefing by Marquis Sunnyvale, where their manganese nodule effort and the Glomar Explorer effort were housed.
This was before the explorer went out and picked up a piece of a submarine.

But they went through the whole exercise for, this was at a COA meeting out at Stanford, went through the whole exercise of how they examined, how they decided whether or not to go into a field like this.
And their first step was to do a complete market study on
on present-day mining, on the grades of ores that are being used to recover copper and other minerals, the potential for finding more of those, the whole market study bit.
And they decided that the copper concentrations, for example, in manganese nodules, is now better, higher, around 2%.
than the copper concentrations in the ores of the mines that they're now mining.
And therefore, they said, then it's worth looking into.
And then they identified all the engineering problems associated with doing that kind of mining.
The first study was a million dollar operation.
Then that engineering study was a $10 million operation, identifying all the engineering problems.
And they, at that time, were in the third step, which costs about $100 million.
And that is tackling the remaining engineering problems.
What kind of a nozzle do you use to pull them up?
Do you use airlift or dredge or what?
And they felt that they had essentially solved the major engineering problems with recovering it from the ocean.
The fourth step, which had cost a billion dollars, and that is to actually start mining and recovering the metals from it and marketing them, was the one they were about to launch into.

And that's the step at which they felt they had to have some assurance, either from the federal government on how the US government was going to protect their interests at sea, or some international agreement on how they'd operate at sea.
And, you know, the Japanese are in it, and the Germans are in it, and the French are in it, and the U.S. is in it.
And I would guess that within no more than 20 years, maybe 10, we'll be recovering medals from the bottom of the sea.
I think once we start, it's going to get easier.
Yeah, but that anticipates another question of mine, and that is,
How are you going to use the sea and utilize the sea?

And how is the foundation going to encourage projects when it becomes fairly apparent with 200-mile boundaries, international agreements, that oceanographers' activities will be more and more limited?
Well, I'm not...
I think it's going to be more difficult for us to operate internationally, but I don't think it's going to be limited.
I think we can work out bilaterals and regional agreements and
international agreements.
And I'm not really pessimistic about being able to do the kind of research we want to in the future.
It's going to take a little bit more planning.
And it may take some funding to solicit participation by some of those countries that we don't now do.
But I think I'm pretty optimistic that we'll be able to go ahead and work.
Good enough.
Now, given the problems in fishing and international cooperation which are developing and international agreements, do you see oceanography moving in perhaps closer to the shores?
That is, with more and more demand for practical oceanography, if I may use that word, for finding finite mineral resources, and with fishing banks, after all, close to our shores itself
Will oceanography come back from the sea rather than go back into deep water?
I think the expansion will be in the shallow water areas and in the continental shelf areas, but I don't see the deep ocean work pulling back from the deep ocean.

because of that i think the ratio will change but it won't be because deepwater people have moved into shallow water you know there isn't that much going on in deepwater the onr and the nsf are the only ones that support deepwater work and all the other agencies work primarily in shallow water so i you know there will there will be a shift in the percentage but
it won't be because the deepwater people pulled out of the sea.
If you were, in the 20 odd years you've been involved in oceanography, what do you consider the tools which have changed the nature of work in oceanography the greatest?
Well, let's see, I would say
Satellite navigation.
STDs.
You know, the Neil Brown type STD.
XPTs.
Curb meter developments.
And the whole raft of geophysical tools.
Seismic reflection, multichannel seismic reflection.
But even before that, even single channel seismic reflection and refraction.
The auto analyzer, which wasn't developed
or oceanographers, but was adopted by them for measurements of nutrients and chemicals aboard ship in large numbers and accurately.
And taking the ship, taking the computer to sea.
Almost everyone says the computer to sea someplace.
Just imagine where they list it.
Instant analyzing of data.
There have been glory fields of oceanography, if I may again use that term.
That is, oceanography essentially began with marine biologists.
Then physical oceanographers seemed to come into sway.
And for a while, people involved in nuclear physics.
What do you think will be the next glory field of oceanography?
You're going to advise us on what hard science to study to become an oceanographer.
What would you suggest?
Oh, that's a tough one.
It would either be chemical or physical oceanography.
And I guess it would be physics for the next few years.
And if you were going to advise an academic department on what sort of oceanographer to try to turn out, what would you suggest?
I would say physics and chemistry.
Now, while you were involved both in your own research and as
a member of a funding agency, what program did you feel to be the most successful, and what program did you feel to be the most disastrous fate?
Depends on what you mean, project?
Project, right, or a project that was to lead to a series of projects, either way.
Well, I think I had a strong hand at ONR for a number of years in developing deep-sea telemetering buoys.
And I thought that's going to be absolutely necessary.
It's the wave of the future.
We'd better get it developed and get to using it.
And I thought I had done everything right.

I had set up a committee of scientists to advise on the development of this hardware all the way along so that when it was ready, we could just hand it to them and they'd take it away and use it, and the whole bit.
And in the end, it turned out that the tool was so expensive and so unreliable, even after putting $10 or $12 million in it, whatever it was,
that it just wasn't suitable as an oceanographic tool.
And I consider that to be pretty much of a disaster for which I had a great deal of responsibility, if not the whole responsibility.
And I feel bad about it.
I just had no idea of how much the things would cost in the end or how difficult it would be to develop a system that you could put in the ocean and leave for a year.
without having something go wrong with some piece of it that would essentially inactivate the whole thing.
And we spent a lot of money using space technology on it, the whole industrial weight of general dynamics, and failure modes, and reliability.
And you get all through, you still don't have a workable tool.
And you don't have one that
that the community can afford to buy very many of them.
And so now I've given up developing systems for oceanographers.
When they come in and say, we want this system for this research task, then we'll try and get the system for them.
But I've given up trying to anticipate what I think they're going to need.
That's probably one of the biggest failures.
The most successful program that I've been associated, had anything to do with, and I haven't had too much to do with, is the Climap program.
And this is the, it's an IDOE project.
Essentially it's a project which the paleontologists who study fossil fuel, fossil in the deep sea sediments, try to say something about the age of the sediments or
when the conditions changed by looking at these fossils in the deep sea core.
And up until we supported the Climap program, each paleontologist was very excited about his own work.
And he would show you micro photographs of forams until you could, you know, you were sick of them.
But there wasn't any, outside of telling you, outside of telling the oil companies whether, what geologic age,
was being examined in the cores.
It didn't tell you an awful lot.
But the scientists at Brown, John Embry, at Lamont, Jim Hayes, at Oregon State University, Ted Moore, put together a program with about 25 to 30 paleontologists.
And they welded them into a team so that they had

each one working on the same core, each one obtaining a different bit of evidence on that core, so that when you put all this evidence together and did some statistical manipulation with it, you could say what the ocean temperature was at that time, at that place, at the surface.
And they developed a map of the Ice Age Ocean 18,000 years ago.
They induced the global
atmospheric modelers to use that data, that picture of the global ocean, to examine their own models and the constants that the modelers were using.
Just a very, very successful program.
If you were to suggest, as a matter of fact,
To young oceanographers, what sort of an education should they receive?
That is, hard science, schools of oceanography.
What direction should schools of oceanography take them?
What would you suggest?
Should they get a general oceanography degree, or should they major in a hard science like you did?
Should oceanography be only graduate study, or should it be undergraduate study?
Well, I think there's

There's no question in my mind that you need a thorough grounding in whatever basic science you're going to operate in before you come into oceanography, because oceanography is just the application of that science to the oceans.
So if you get an undergraduate degree in oceanography, you don't have any strength in any particular field, not physics, not mathematics, or anything else, and you really end up more
at a technician role than you do at a researcher role.
And some of the most successful people have gone on and got their PhDs in the hard science, in chemistry or in physics, and then come into oceanography as a matter of interest.
And in fact, that's where they all came from initially.
And that's still where many of the good ones come from.
But oceanography is training.
their own experts now, very successfully, they can compete with.
Monk came in that way, and Stommel came in that way.
All of the older group of people, it's the only way they could get in, as a matter of fact.
But I would certainly, I think, if you want to say I'd like to work in the field at the technical level, at the technician level,
then you get an undergraduate degree.
But if you really want to do research, your own research, an advanced way forward, you really have to have an undergraduate degree in a basic science.
Which oceanographer possibly had the greatest influence on directing your career?
On my career?
Your career.
Well, you know, not from a professional point of view, but from... And I guess that's not the question.
The question is from a professional point of view.
I take it from any point of view.
Well, you know, obviously Maxwell taught me in the coming into the field, and he coerced me into going to Washington, so he had a profound impact on my career.
As far as...
professional end of it, I suppose Ted Folsom, who I worked with closely for about six years before I joined ONR, probably had the most, the largest impact.
Have you had any regrets that you chose to become a, may I use the word, political oceanographer rather than an academic oceanographer?
No, no, I don't, I'm not a,
particularly strong research type.
And I faced that shortly after I came to ONR.
I decided I surely had a better management capability than I had a research capability.
And so it was not really difficult for me to make the decision.
And I certainly never regret it.
Are you going to say a few words about where you think the focus of research will be?
Yeah, by that I don't mean in physics or in chemistry.
What I really am referring to is the annual decision or the annual approach by Congress to put all of oceanography into one super agency.
In this country today and since the early 60s, the real oceanographic strength of this country has been at the academic institutions, at the universities.
And I think this is the reason that the country leads the world in oceanography, because of the academic atmosphere.
and the impact of the students on their professors in tackling various problems and in keeping them sharpened up.
And so I get concerned when we talk about giving responsibility for supporting research to an agency with an in-house capability.
And I'm going to do whatever I can to make sure

at the basic research component, the research component of the country stays that the university is supported through grants and contracts from whatever source, and that that pot of money is protected very carefully by the federal government, from inroads, by in-house laboratories.
And I have a strong conviction

from my days at ONR and watching the Air Force turn the responsibility for their basic research in geophysics over to the geophysics research directorate, which was a laboratory up in Massachusetts, and then watching their contract research program disappear.
It's very easy to say, well, I need a million dollars because I've got a laboratory with a whole bunch of civil servants in it.
And therefore, we just take it away from the contract research program.
this year, give it back next year.
And, you know, just this continual encroachment of in-house versus contract research.
It's kind of insidious.
Now, by in-house...
I mean in-house Navy labs, NOAA laboratories, EPA laboratories.
I think these are necessary for carefully applied research and to answer questions that these...
that these agencies need for their own mission.
But I get concerned that, for example, in the Sea Grant Program, which is in NOAA, that they might have difficulty protecting that from other parts of NOAA, because it's a grant.
a grant program.
Universities are violently opposed to this idea of a super agency to administer funds.
This is one of the common things that oceanographers talk about.
So you think the fear may well be from competition with in-house agencies?
Oh, I don't know whether that's their fear or not.
I think they'd like to have more than one place to go to.
All right, now that's what I said.

Their words always, what I always hear is we'd like to have several agencies to try our ideas out on because an agency tends to favor certain kinds of ideas and become sort of locked into those ideas.
Yeah, I think it's, I think their concerns are valid ones.
And in fact, the foundation, the whole foundation's policy is to encourage other agencies to support basic research.

But when you start talking about an agency or an office which will be responsible for all of oceanography or all of environmental sciences, or in the case of energy, all of energy, you have to be very careful about how you set it up.
particularly with regard to the basic social research component that's just a holly horse right around well i'm interested in that i want to ask more questions about that
